nodes.text: Differences in early European settler mortality causally affected long-run economic performance by shaping colonial settlement decisions which produced different institutions that persisted to the present and influence income per capita
Higher European settler mortality reduced the feasibility of long-term European settlement in colonies

Presence or absence of European settlers determined colonial policies: settler colonies tended to establish protective, property-rights institutions while nonsettler colonies tended to create extractive institutions
Colonial institutions persisted after independence and formed the basis for contemporary institutions
Method: Use historical European settler mortality as an instrumental variable for current institutions to estimate the causal effect of institutions on income per capita

Data sources and measures: settler mortality from Curtin and historical records (soldiers, bishops, sailors), institutions proxied by Political Risk Services index of protection against expropriation (1985–1995), and GDP per capita (PPP)

First-stage evidence: log settler mortality strongly negatively predicts contemporary protection-against-expropriation institutions; settler mortality explains about 25–30 percent of institutional variation

IV (two-stage least squares) result: instrumenting institutions with log settler mortality yields a large, statistically significant positive effect of institutions on log income per capita (baseline IV coef. ~0.94; robust across samples and alternative outcomes)

Robustness: IV estimates are robust to controls for latitude, climate, current disease prevalence (malaria, life expectancy, infant mortality), colonizer identity, legal origin, religion, natural resources, soil quality, ethnolinguistic fragmentation, and sample exclusions (Neo-Europes, Africa)

Biological mechanism: major causes of high settler mortality were malaria and yellow fever which were highly fatal to nonimmune Europeans but had limited fatal effects on indigenous adult populations because of acquired immunity and genetic traits

Typology of colonization: 'Neo-Europes' (e.g., US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand) where settlers replicated European institutions vs extractive colonies (e.g., Congo, many African and some Latin American colonies) oriented to resource extraction and weak property rights

Historical evidence and examples: documented cases (Sierra Leone, Madagascar, Congo, British settler colonies) show mortality influenced settlement choices and that settler societies pressured for representative institutions while extractive regimes prioritized extraction

Mechanisms for institutional persistence: sunk costs of building rule-of-law institutions, small elite capture favoring extractive rules, and irreversible investments complementary to existing institutions cause long-run persistence of colonial institutions

Validity checks: overidentification tests using additional instruments (early institutions, settlement measures, yellow fever dummy) find no evidence that settler mortality has a direct effect on current income other than through institutions

Conclusion and policy implication: improving institutions plausibly yields large long-run income gains; colonial origins are an important but not immutable determinant, suggesting potential welfare gains from institutional reform
